title: FailOnTimeout should use daemon thread and internal fields should be treated as final and volatile
body:
+ daemon threads for comfortable use
+ treated field for safety reasons in multi-threading

title: Prepare 4.12 development
body:
* Increment version number in `build.xml`
* Add empty release notes file to start collecting them right away

title: Fixed a JDK5 backwards compatibility issue introduced in Pull #542
body:
In fixing issue #144 a JDK6 API call was accidentally introduced.
Updated to be compatible with JDK5.

title: fixes for #544 and #545
body:
Simple fixes for #544 and #545.

Changes:

+ FailOnTimeout is now daemon thred.
+ StatementThread in FailOnTimeout uses volatile variables.
+ StatementThread  catching two more exceptions when a thread is interrupted: InterruptedIOException and ClosedByInterruptException.
+ added NIO tests to TimeoutRuleTest.

title: Pull request for issue #157
body: Removed `@Deprecated` annotation for methods `withBefores` and `withAfters` in `BlockJUnit4ClassRunner`.

title: MethodSorterTest fails when run with Jacoco Coverage
body:
Three of the test cases from `org.junit.internal.MethodSorterTest` fail when the junit test suite is executed with Jacoco coverage enabled in Eclipse. I suspect the same failure will occur with other coverage analysis tools. Having this fixed helps in order to have a JUnit's coverage analyzed in a continuous integration tool.

The cause of the problem is that Jacoco generates extra methods to conduct the instrumentation, which are then included in the sorted result (and which the test case does not expect).

A simple solution is to refine the equality check so that only the order of the methods actually declared is verified.

I've this solution almost ready, which I'll post as a pull request once I'm done.

title: Time Watcher
body:
If you want to measure time spent by a test, you have to do one of the following:

+ use try-finally and measure the time within the test; or
+ use @Before and @After, cache the start time, and compute the time spent in @After. Good luck with parallel tests, because there you have to use ThreadLocal.

The Rules is an elegant solution for that.

title: Badly formatted javadoc for Parameterized
body:
When displaying the javadoc for 4.11 Parameterized in Eclipse, the mixture of tabs and spaces means that the sample code isn't formatted nicely.

Also, the sample naming scheme doesn't display correctly in the junit runner in Eclipse. So "foo(bar)" gets displayed as "foo".

title: Fixes #553, formatted sample code in javadoc
body: Changed the sample annotation to "{index}: fib[{0}]={1}", to avoid the use of ().

title: Fix for MethodSorterTest so that coverage can be measured (issue #551)
body:
**The issue (#551):**
With [Jacoco](http://www.eclemma.org/jacoco/) (formerly eclemma) code coverage enabled in Eclipse, the `org.junit.internal.MethodSorterTest` failed on
* `getMethodsNullSorter`
* `testDefaultSorter`
* `testNameAsc`

The cause was that via reflection methods were collected from static classes. These included temporary methods generated by the coverage tool, which were not expected by the test causing the test to fail.

**The fix**
To fix this, I filter methods before comparison, to just the methods actually declared. This is done by the new `getDeclaredFilteredMethods` helper method. As a result, all tests pass both with and without coverage analysis enabled.

I also applied some small refactorings. I extracted separate test cases for method sorting on sub and superclasses (which were included in the null sorter test case). Furthermore, I based all equality checks directly on lists or arrays, instead of on the `toString` representation of objects.

title: Problem with special character in @Parameterized(name= "")
assertEquals(String, float, float, float) can cause some legacy code to call a different assertion in 4.11
body:
Hi,
I have the following assertion:
assertEquals("blah", -152589047, -152589048, 1);

The assertion succeeds when JUnit 4.10 is used, but it fails with JUnit 4.11:
java.lang.AssertionError: blah expected:<-1.52589056E8> but was:<-1.5258904E8>
	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
	at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:519)

I am using java-6-sun-1.6.0.26 on Ubuntu / 32 bit

title: Inheritance of Categories
Provide an API or annotation to specify a class to use to order the test methods
body: When adding this annotation to a test super class -> it is not taken into account

title: Default method order should be taken from a project configuration option
body: It can be a system property, environment variable, anything so that it is easy to set the method order once for a whole project

title: Optional inheritance of Categories
body: Please ignore this. I filed a new pull request.

title: Add a README.md
body: Add a README.md to the root of the repository. There, we can easily add an image and a link to the Jenkins instance on CloudBees.  (To meet our requirements for free CloudBees hosting)

title: Optional class-level inheritance of @Category annotated classes
body: Please see https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/issues/558 for more info. It would be more easy to just add @inherited to the Category-annotation but some people were afraid that this will confuse users due to changed behaviour.

title: Allow configurable creation of child runners of parameterized suites
body:
I would like to be able to customize the creation of `Runner`s used by `Parameterized` to run each combination of parameters.

This would allow me to customize `withBefores()`, `withAfters()`, etc. of child `Runner`s, e.g. to create custom filtering of lifecycle methods.

title: Enables class-array as parameter to @IncludeCategory and @ExludeCategory
body: As discussed here: https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/142 and here: https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/503 people are in urgent! need of specifying more than one Class in @ExcludeCategory and @IncludeCategory. It was discussed that there has to be a more sophisticated implementation (ALL/ANY) but I do not really think so. Even if: I would suggest accepting the simple solution as this means a fast benefit for everyone. In the end Selection is a compatible addition and not a different approach.

title: Enables Inheritance on Category.java by adding @Inherited
body: As discussed in https://github.com/KentBeck/junit/pull/563 @dsaff suggested to try and add @Inherited. This pull request introduces that behaviour.

title: Update 4.12 Release Notes for #552
Multiple Categories #503
body: The pull #503 is continuing here.

No Javadoc for version 4.11 published

title: Ensuring no-generic-type-parms validator called/tested for theories
body: I had this stuff in junit.contrib/theories but not the experimental theories stuff in JUnit proper. Whoops.

title: Ensuring no-generic-type-parms validator called/tested for theories
Theory that fails may return a more explanatory message
body:
Actually, when a @theory fails, it throws a ParameterizedAssertionError that gives theory's method name and used argument(s) : ok, we know **what** failed. 
But to know **why** it failed, one have to go deep down the stack trace (20+ lines of call stack) to retrieve the root cause of the failure, obviously the message returned by the failing assertion.

*Example :*
There was 1 failure:
    1) returnFizzWhenValueIsAMultipleOfThree(FizzBuzzTest)
    org.junit.experimental.theories.internal.ParameterizedAssertionError: returnFizzWhenValueIsAMultipleOfThree(three)
    at 
   *** Starting from here, information is irrelevant when trying to understand why a theory failed***
org.junit.experimental.theories.Theories$TheoryAnchor.reportParameterizedError(Theories.java:183)
   <26 lines of call stack cut>
   ...    
   at org.junit.runner.JUnitCore.main(JUnitCore.java:38)
   
**    Caused by: org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<[fizz]> but was:<[a string]>** At least !!
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:124)
...


I would suggest to add assertion failure message as a part of the ParameterizedAssertionError, in order to have all relevant and needed information on the very first line of the stack trace.

title: Check Test-class members implementing TestRule are annotated with @Rule or @ClassRule
body:
The other way around already exists - checking that a field annotated with @(Class)Rule implements TestRule - I wonder why it only works one-way.

I recently forgot to add the @Rule annotation to a rule and wondered why my test didn't run. Even worse, it can lead to undetected misbehavior if you forget to annotate your Rule properly. With a SystemPropertyRule, for example, leaving out the @Rule annotation leads to the Rule behaving properly within the Test, but not resetting the System Property after the test has run.

A simple fix would be to reflectively go through the fields of the Test-class and ensure, that all field types implementing TestRule are marked with @(Class)Rule (and all methods returning a type implementing TestRule).

On approval, I would implement the change and submit a pull request.

title: FixMethodOrder annotation on superclasses, see issue 559
body: Check all superclass for the FixMethodOrder annotation
